values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the major theories and issues in international politics. The goals of the course are to give students a broad familiarity with the field of international relations, and to help them develop the analytical skills necessary to think critically about international politics. The course is divided into four parts: 1) Concepts and Theories of International Relations; 2) War and Security; 3) The Global Economy; and 4) Emerging Issues in International Relations. 

Many students said that the class helped them gain a firm foundation for future International Relations classes. Students thought that the class was well organized, but found the lectures to be occasionally somewhat dry. 

Students praised Professor Stanton for being very accessible and friendly. Students thought Professor Stanton’s lectures were very well planned and thought that “her enthusiasm for teaching the class showed;” however, at times, the lectures were “too rehearsed.” One student praised Professor Stanton for her ability to relate lecture material to assigned readings. 

This class fulfills the Society requirement and is a good introductory class for students interested in International Relations. Though some students found there to be too much reading, most students found the workload to be manageable. Students complained about the harshness of the grading curve for an introductory course and thought tests and papers were graded “very strictly”.
